etymologies: Old English mūs, (plural) mȳs, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch muis and German Maus, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin and Greek mus

notes.text: Is the plural of mouse in the computing sense mice or mouses? People often feel that this sense needs its own distinctive plural, but in fact the ordinary plural mice is commoner, and the first recorded use of the term in the plural (1984) is mice

definitions: a small rodent that typically has a pointed snout, relatively large ears and eyes, and a long tail.

notes.text: Family Muridae: many genera and numerous species. Also, some species in the families Heteromyidae, Zapodidae, and Muscardinidae

definitions: (in general use) any small mammal similar to a mouse, such as a shrew or vole.
a shy, timid, and quiet person

examples.text: Jane may be a bit of a mouse, but she is very nosy

definitions: a dull light brown colour reminiscent of a mouse's fur

examples.text: her flaxen hair dulled to mouse

definitions: a small handheld device which is moved across a mat or flat surface to move the cursor on a computer screen

examples.text: copy the file with a click of the mouse

definitions: a lump or bruise on or near the eye

examples.text: she touched the mouse under her eye

notes.text: Is the plural of mouse in the computing sense mice or mouses? People often feel that this sense needs its own distinctive plural, but in fact the ordinary plural mice is commoner, and the first recorded use of the term in the plural (1984) is mice

definitions: (of a cat or owl) hunt for or catch mice

examples.text: female cats are usually much better at mousing than males
he was mousing among the books of the old library

definitions: use a mouse to move or position a cursor on a computer screen

examples.text: simply mouse over any item on the list
